top_comments_top.body:
As a reminder, this subreddit [is for civil discussion.](/r/politics/wiki/index#wiki_be_civil)

In general, be courteous to others. Debate/discuss/argue the merits of ideas, don't attack people. Personal insults, shill or troll accusations, hate speech, any suggestion or support of harm, violence, or death, and other rule violations can result in a permanent ban. 

If you see comments in violation of our rules, please report them.

 For those who have questions regarding any media outlets being posted on this subreddit, please click [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/politics/wiki/approveddomainslist) to review our details as to our approved domains list and outlet criteria.

***


*I am a bot, and this action was performed automatically. Please [contact the moderators of this subreddit](/message/compose/?to=/r/politics) if you have any questions or concerns.*
No, he can't. I'm guessing Republicans will make gains during the midterms, progressives will be blamed for the loss in seats, and the rotational hellscape will continue unabated.

I seriously doubt it. Corporate America has enough bought politicians to maintain the status quo.

It's blatantly clear that the will of the American people has been ignored in favor of run away capitalism and the money controlling it.

Until corporations and dark money are removed from politics, we don't have a snowball's chance in hell. Unfortunately, way too many politicians are beholden to big money to vote against their and their controller's interests.

>Can?

Yes, he actually has pretty wide latitude to do many things through executive regulatory action. He can't do everything he said he wanted, but he can to a hell of a lot of it.

&#x200B;

**Will?**  

No. If he was going to enact policies he fought against for almost 40 years in public office and continued to argue against them until late in the Primaries (when he didn't wait until late October to flip flop) then he would have already done so.  Democrats have been using the same excuses my entire life...

1. We aren't the majority
2. We are the majority, but not a "real" majority
3. We are a majority with votes to do it, but if it's not bi-partisan then we shouldn't do it.
